refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: A gtk.gdk.Event represents an event from the windowing system. The gtk.gdk.Event methods are usually not used by applications since the PyGTK main loop generates signals and invokes the appropriate signal handler. The event types are:

listitem.simpara: a special code to indicate a null event.
the window manager has requested that the toplevel window be hidden or destroyed, usually when the user clicks on a special icon in the title bar.
the window has been destroyed.
all or part of the window has become visible and needs to be redrawn.
the pointer (usually a mouse) has moved.
a mouse button has been pressed.
a mouse button has been double-clicked (clicked twice within a short period of time). Note that each click also generates a gtk.gdk.BUTTON_PRESS event.
a mouse button has been clicked 3 times in a short period of time. Note that each click also generates a gtk.gdk.BUTTON_PRESS event.
a mouse button has been released.
a key has been pressed.
a key has been released.
the pointer has entered the window.
the pointer has left the window.
the keyboard focus has entered or left the window.
the size, position or stacking order of the window has changed. Note that PyGTK discards these events for gtk.gdk.WINDOW_CHILD windows.
the window has been mapped.
the window has been unmapped.
a property on the window has been changed or deleted.
the application has lost ownership of a selection.
another application has requested a selection.
a selection has been received.
an input device has moved into contact with a sensing surface (e.g. a touchscreen or graphics tablet).
an input device has moved out of contact with a sensing surface.
the mouse has entered the window while a drag is in progress.
the mouse has left the window while a drag is in progress
the mouse has moved in the window while a drag is in progress.
the status of the drag operation initiated by the window has changed.
a drop operation onto the window has started.
the drop operation initiated by the window has completed.
a message has been received from another application.
the window visibility status has changed.
indicates that the source region was completely available when parts of a drawable were copied. This is not very useful.
a scroll had occurred for a window
the window state has changed
a setting has changed
the owner of a selection has changed. Added in GTK+ 2.6
a pointer or keyboard grab was broken. Added in GTK+ 2.8.

refsect1.para: A set of bit-flags is used to indicate which events a window is to receive. Most of these masks map onto one or more of the event types above. Use the gtk.Widget.set_events() method to indicate which events a widget should receive.

The gtk.gdk.POINTER_MOTION_HINT_MASK is a special mask which is used to reduce the number of gtk.gdk.MOTION_NOTIFY events received. Normally a gtk.gdk.MOTION_NOTIFY event is received each time the mouse moves. However, if the application spends a lot of time processing the event (updating the display, for example), it can easily lag behind the position of the mouse. When using the gtk.gdk.POINTER_MOTION_HINT_MASK the server will only send a single gtk.gdk.MOTION_NOTIFY event (which is marked as a hint) until the application asks for more, by calling the gtk.gdk.Window.get_pointer() method. The masks are:
gtk.gdk.ALL_EVENTS_MASK is a combination of all the event masks.

Starting with PyGTK 2.14 gtk.gdk.Event objects have custom support for repr Python function. Text representation will include event type and a few most important event attributes, e.g. x, y and button for gtk.gdk.BUTTON_PRESS events. However, round-tripping through eval(repr(event)) is not possible: representation string uses <...> form.

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.Event.put
refsect2.para: The put() method appends a copy of the given event onto the tail of the event queue.

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.Event.copy

listitem.simpara: a copy of the event

refsect2.para: The copy() method copies the event, copying or incrementing the reference count of the resources associated with it (e.g. windows and strings).

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.Event.free

warning.para: This method is deprecated and should not be used since it may crash your application.

refsect2.para: The free() method frees the event, freeing or decrementing any resources associated with it. Note that this method should only be called on gtk.gdk.Event objects returned from methods or functions such as gtk.gdk.event_peek(), gtk.gdk.event_get(), gtk.gdk.event_get_graphics_expose() and copy().

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.Event.get_time

listitem.simpara: the time stamp field from the event

refsect2.para: The get_time() method returns the time stamp from the event, if there is one; otherwise returns 0.

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.Event.get_state

listitem.simpara: the modifier state

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.4 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_state() method returns the value of the modifier "state" field. If the event has no "state" field the empty state value (0) is returned. The "state" field contains a modifier type: a combination of the .

blockquote.para: These events do not have any additional attributes.

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.Event.get_coords

listitem.simpara: a tuple containing the event window x and y coordinates or an empty tuple if the event did not deliver event window coordinates

refsect2.para: The get_coords() method returns a tuple containing the x and y coordinates of an event relative to the event gtk.gdk.Window or an empty tuple if the event did not deliver event window coordinates.

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.Event.get_root_coords

listitem.simpara: a tuple containing the root window x and y coordinates or an empty tuple if the event did not deliver root window coordinates

refsect2.para: The get_root_coords() method returns a tuple containing the x and y coordinates from an event relative to the root window or an empty tuple if the event did not deliver root window coordinates.

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.Event.get_axis

listitem.simpara: the axis use to look for
the value found or None if the axis was not found.

refsect2.para: The get_axis() method returns the axis value for the axis use specified by axis_use from an event structure. The value of axis_use must be one of:

listitem.simpara: the axis is ignored.
the axis is used as the x axis.
the axis is used as the y axis.
the axis is used for pressure information.
the axis is used for x tilt information.
the axis is used for y tilt information.
the axis is used for wheel information.
a constant equal to the numerically highest axis value.

refsect2.para: If an axis with the specified axis use is not found, this method returns None.

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.Event.set_screen

listitem.simpara: a gtk.gdk.Screen

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.2 and above.

refsect2.para: The set_screen() method sets the gtk.gdk.Screen to the value of screen. The event must have been allocated by PyGTK, for instance, by the gtk.gdk.Event.copy() method.

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.Event.get_screen

listitem.simpara: the screen for the event

note.para: This method is available in PyGTK 2.2 and above.

refsect2.para: The get_screen() method returns the gtk.gdk.Screen for the event. The screen is typically the screen for the event window, but for events such as mouse events, it is the screen where the the pointer was when the event occurs - that is, the screen that has the root window for the event.

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.events_pending

listitem.simpara: True if any events are pending

refsect2.para: The gtk.gdk.events_pending() function returns True if any events are ready to be processed.

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.event_peek

listitem.simpara: a copy of the first gtk.gdk.Event on the event queue or None if there is no event in the queue.

refsect2.para: The gtk.gdk.event_peek() function returns a copy of the first gtk.gdk.Event on the event queue or None if there is no event on the event queue.

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.event_get

listitem.simpara: the next gtk.gdk.Event to be processed, or None if no events are pending.

refsect2.para: The gtk.gdk.event_get() function returns the next gtk.gdk.Event to be processed or None if no events are available.

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.event_get_graphics_expose

listitem.simpara: a gtk.gdk.Window
an expose gtk.gdk.Event if a GraphicsExpose was received, or None if a NoExpose event was received.

refsect2.para: The gtk.gdk.event_get_graphics_expose() function waits for and returns returns an expose gtk.gdk.Event if a GraphicsExpose was received, or None if a NoExpose event was received.

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.set_show_events

listitem.simpara: if True output event debug information

refsect2.para: The gtk.gdk.set_show_events() function sets the debug events flag if show_events is True. Otherwise the debug events flag is unset.

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.get_show_events

listitem.simpara: True if the debug events flag is set.

refsect2.para: The gtk.gdk.get_show_events() function returns the setting of the internal debug events flag.

refsect2.title: gtk.gdk.event_request_motions

listitem.simpara: a valid gtk.gdk.Event

note.para: This function is available in PyGTK 2.12 and above.

refsect2.para: The gtk.gdk.event_request_motions() function request more motion notifies if event is a motion notify hint event. This function should be used instead of gtk.gdk.Window.get_pointer() to request further motion notifies, because it also works for extension events where motion notifies are provided for devices other than the core pointer.
